   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension and end stage
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures now
   transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
   Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Pt with h/o HF and COPD,
   so likely mutifactorial. Lasix and Lisinopril were held and the pt was
   receiving IVF
s which could have tipped him over towards pulmonary
   edema although imaging doesn
t fully support this. Requires 2L O2 at
   baseline. Also seen to have bilateral opacifications at the bases.
   - Continue with Levofloxacin for CAP, today is day [**1-31**]
   - Follow speciation of initial 1+ GNR
s on sputum Cx
   - lasix 40 mg IV BID as blood pressure will tolerate
   - Captopril was held yesterday for low bp. If bp can tolerate through
   today, would add it back for afterload reduction.
   - Metoprolol 25 mg PO BID for heart failure
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive
   component
   - Pressure support has been weaned from 10
 5 and pt is oxygenating
   well
   - CO2
s continue to be in the high 50
s, which may be were pt lives
   chronically with h/o COPD.
   - SBT today with plans to wean and hopefully extubated
   - Will need scheduled nebs after extubation.
   Tachycardia: Sepsis vs volume depletion vs anemia with falling Hct vs
   didn
t get beta blockade on the floor. Volume depletion less likely as
   pt with good bp, has been net positive through yesterday and was not
   getting Lasix on the floor. Could be evolving septic picture as pt with
   low grade temps over yesterday and h/o temp to 102 recently. BCx
   negative to date.
   - Metoprolol 25 mg PO BID
   - Watch BCx
s and continue Levofloxacin for now, if appears to be
   getting more septic, broaden coverage
   Hypotension: Patient transiently hypotensive in the setting of
   receiving large doses of metoprolol, diltiazem, propofol and induction
   agents for intubation.  Then seen to have episode of hypotension after
   admission which has now resolved and pt is mildly hypertensive
   currently.
   - Have switched to Fentanyl Versed instead of Propofol for sedation
   - Consider small amts of fluids if hypotense with h/o CHF
   - follow blood cultures
   - Restarted on home dose of steroids
   Delerium: Unclear etiology.  Differential diagnosis includes
   medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities etc.  Urinalysis
   negative.  Blood cultures pending.  [**Month (only) 60**] have small pneumonia on xray.
   ABG intially with well compensated respiratory acidosis now with acute
   decompensation.  Morphine may be contributing.
   - Tylenol and Fentanyl for pain as needed
   - - follow blood and urine cultures
   - PRN zydis for agitation
   - Will try to wean sedation through today and see how his mental status
   is
   Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for operative
   intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   slightly worsened at 1.9 and rising.
   - Consider small amts of fluids, also if hypotensive, but need to be
   careful with h/o CHF
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.  No
   signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past 48
   hours.
   - active type and screen
 outdates [**2109-11-3**]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Trend Hct
 repeat this pm
   - iron deficient
 start PO iron through NGT and bowel regimen
   - Folate, B12 normal
   - Iron studies more consistent with ACD
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   Hypertension: Transiently hypotensive in the setting of medications.
   Would likely benefit from resuming afterload reduction in the setting
   of severe MR/AR.
   - Can restart Captopril 12.5 mg TID if not having any more hypotension
   through today
   - Continue metoprolol 25 mg PO BID
   Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV BID
   - captopril 12.5 mg TID
   - resume metoprolol
   - I/O goal -1  liter today as bp can tolerate
   COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing
   Gout:
   - continue home prednisone
   - holding allopurinol
   Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy:
   - holding agents while has foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds
    Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin. Will start PPI today.
    Access: femoral line (will remove if hemodynamically stable after
   extubation and not requiring central access), arterial line
    Code:  Full (discussed with son)
    Communication: Patient,  son [**Name (NI) 3080**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10783**]
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

   I saw & examined the pt & was physically present with the ICU team for
   the key portions of services provided. I agree w/Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 10784**]
s note
   above, including assessment and plan. I would add:
   89 yo male admitted for wrist and odontoid fracture. Course complicated
   by hypercarbic and hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation
   with TSICU-->MICU transfer [**11-1**]. Suspect inciting factor of pulmonary
   edema from skipped diuretics +/- PNA with poor reserve from
   pre-existing COPD/CHF
   24 hour events: transiently hypotensive in the context of beta-blocker
   +propofol+ captopril. Received 250cc bolus with improvt
   Rx: Lopressor
   pepcid
   Hep, LVQ, alb, SSI
   Bolus fentanyl and versed for sedation
   Exam
   I/O 1.5 liter positive
   Vent: PSV 5/5 FiO2 30; ABG 7.35/53/86
   Intubated
   [**Location (un) 2420**] J collar
   Lungs: fair air movement
   CV: sys murmur at apex, diastolic [**1-30**] at USB
   Abd +bs, soft nontender
   Ext: no edema
   WBC 9, Hct 26 (30, 2 days ago)
   Bun/Cr 35/1.9
   Imp:
   89 yo male with valvular HD/COPD /chronic aspiration admitted with
   odontoid fracture and wrist fracture; course c/b hypercarbic
   respiratory failure
   1. acute Resp failure:
   Doing well on SBT, though remain concerned that pulmonary edema could
   be an issue once extubated
   lasix 40 mg IV now then goal fluid balance negative 1 liters\; Check
   BNP
   Will move to extubate
   Continue LVQ for LLL infiltrate; Change alb/atrovent inhalers to
   scheduled nebs
   2. HTN: BP meds held due to hypotension (sedation +meds)- will
   introduce back into regimen gradually
   3. AMS: Reportedly more combative on the floor, though currently not
   requiring much sedation. Will re-assess once pt extubated, re-orient
   pt, family at bedside, assess pain
   4. wrist and odontoid fracture: No surgical intervention planned-
   5. Anemia: Hct lower today, no obvious bleeding. Will guiac stools,
   trend hct's
   Rest of plan per ICU team
   Pt is crit. Ill. Total time spent: 40 min.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 749**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], MD
   on:[**2109-11-3**] 14:05 ------
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was admitted for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently in the ICU. The patient has several medical complications, including atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, impaired transfers, impaired gait, impaired balance, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, and impaired knowledge.

The patient's recent events include being found down in his living area, odontoid and right wrist fractures, and the transfer from the TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with pressure support. He is also receiving IV fluids, Lasix, Metoprolol, Prednisone, and other medications as needed.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C (100°F), heart rate of 114 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 152/37 to 161/45 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15-31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's physical examination reveals fair air movement in the lungs, a systolic murmur at the apex, and diastolic murmur at the USB.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, creatinine, troponin-T, and lactic acid levels. Imaging studies indicate

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and transferred from the TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 114 bpm, blood pressure of 152/37 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. He is intubated and responsive to external stimuli. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation, odontoid and right wrist fractures, and a previous episode of hypoxia and hypercarbia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient requires 2L O2 at baseline, indicating respiratory distress. Bilateral opacifications at the lung bases suggest aspiration, pneumonia, or less likely atelectasis. Lasix and Lisinopril were held, and the patient received IV fluids, which could have contributed to pulmonary edema.

2. Sepsis: The patient has low-grade temperatures and a recent history of fever. Blood cultures are pending, and there is a possibility of evolving septicemia. Broadening coverage may be necessary if the patient appears to be getting more septic.

3. Hypotension:

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found unconscious in his living apartment and transferred from the TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient's current medications include Levofloxacin, Metoprolol, Lasix IV, and Prednisone. 

The patient's recent events include being admitted to the ICU, initiation of Levofloxacin, Metoprolol, and Lasix IV, weaning of PS from 10 to 5, current RR in the 20's, saturation at 95%, and administration of Lopressor, which resulted in a drop in blood pressure to the 80's. Propofol was stopped, Captopril was discontinued, and Lasix was held. A 250cc bolus was given.

The patient's allergies include no known drug allergies. His last dose of antibiotics was Vancomycin on 11/2/2109 at 12:00 AM, Ciprofloxacin on 11/2/2109 at 12:03 PM, and Cefepime on 11/2/2109 at 02:13 PM.

Infusions include Furosemide (Lasix), Metoprolol, Heparin Sodium (prophylaxis), Famotidine (Pepcid), Midazolam (Versed), and Fentanyl.

The patient's physical examination reveals that he is intubated, responsive to external stimuli, but does not open his eyes to voice or follow commands. His lungs show upper airway breath sounds with fair air movement. Heart sounds are clear with a systolic and slight diastolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border and left lower sternal border. His abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended with no grimacing when palpated. His left arm is in a cast, and there is no evidence of lower extremity edema.

Laboratory results show a WBC count of 11.0, Hct of 30.8, Plt of 299,000/mm3, Cr of 1.9, Troponin-T of 0.02, TCO2 of 33, and Glucose of 109 mg/dL. Other lab results are within normal limits. Imaging studies reveal bilateral opacification at the lung bases, likely due to aspiration pneumonia or atelectasis. There is also evidence of small right pleural effusion, cardiomegaly, stable ascending aortic aneurysm, and emphysema. A CT head shows areas of low attenuation in the periventricular and subcortical white matter, consistent with chronic small vessel ischemic changes, as well as a possible lytic area at the anterior edge of C1, likely a degenerative cyst.

The patient's assessment and plan include atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, impaired transfers, impaired gait, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, and impaired balance. The patient's conditions include hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, delirium, right wrist fracture, dens fracture, chronic kidney disease, anemia, hypertension, congestive heart failure, and COPD. The patient's code status is DNR/DNI.

Potential medical complications that can arise include sepsis, volume depletion, anemia, hypotension, delirium, pneumonia, chronic kidney disease exacerbation, congestive heart failure exacerbation, and COPD exacerbation.

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient's current condition includes atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, impaired transfers, impaired gait, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, and impaired balance. He is also experiencing tachycardia, hypotension, delirium, a right wrist fracture, a dens fracture, chronic kidney disease, anemia, hypertension, congestive heart failure, and COPD.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of COPD and acute exacerbation, which can lead to respiratory failure. His current condition includes hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which increases the risk of clot formation and potential embolic events.
3. Fractures: The patient has sustained two fractures, a right wrist fracture and a dens fracture. These fractures may require medical intervention and rehabilitation.
4. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient has chronic kidney disease, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and further complications if not managed properly.
5. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit levels are in the high 20s, indicating anemia. Further investigation and management are needed to determine the underlying cause

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension and end stage
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures now
   transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Primarily caused by
   acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia.  Improved with diuresis and on room air, as home sats are
   likely in the low 90s and similar.  His sats vary widely depending on
   if he is clearing his secretions, but typically improve with
   suctioning.  On levofloxacin day [**2-28**] today for CAP, given 750mg PO
   QOD.  We will restart diuresis as heart failure is playing a large
   role.
   - levofloxacin 750 mg PO every other day for community acquired
   pneumonia w/ renal failure
   - follow up sputum cultures
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, f/u I/O
s and PM lytes to reassess need for
   second dose.
   - stop captopril to avoid hypotension
   - increase metoprolol to 25 mg PO QID to help tachycardia and HTN.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive
   component
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs. [**Month (only) 60**] be related to mild volume overload
   versus mild infection.  Given concern for congestive heart failure will
   resume patient's home beta blocker and diurese.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   #) s/p femoral line site bleed: Unclear why he had such a severe bleed
   after removal of a venous line with a normal INR and normal platelets.
   Received 1U PRBC with an appropriate bump.  Appears to have been an
   isolated event.
   #) Delerium: Was delirius with an unclear etiology.  Differential
   diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities
   etc.  Urinalysis negative.  Blood cultures pending.  This has improved,
   and he seems to do best with his family at the bedside.
   - tylenol for pain
   - low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   - follow blood and urine cultures
   - PRN zydis for agitation
   - Encourage OOB.
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   slightly worsened at 1.8.
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - titrate diuresis to avoid large rise in creatinine.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.
   No signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past
   48 hours.  Appears on labs to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - stop captopril
   - metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal - 1 liter today
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Gout:
   - continue home prednisone
   - holding allopurinol
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy:
   - holding agents while has foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin
   Access: multiple PIVs, arterial line

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment prior to admission and has been transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius (100.7 degrees Fahrenheit), a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 136/30 to 160/41 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's physical examination reveals clear lung sounds with upper airway breath sounds, fair air movement, and a systolic and slight diastolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border and left lower sternal border. 

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin levels, increased creatinine level, and abnormal electrolyte levels. The imaging shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, blunting of the left costophrenic sinus suggesting a small pleural effusion, and mild-to-moderate retrocardiac atelectasis. 

The patient's assessment includes electrolyte and fluid disorder, altered mental status, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, impaired transfers, impaired gait, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired balance, impaired knowledge, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation, upper extremity fracture,

He was found down in his living apartment and transferred from the TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient has several medical complications, including electrolyte and fluid disorder, altered mental status, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, impaired transfers, gait, aerobic capacity/endurance, balance, and knowledge.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is primarily caused by acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened by hypertension and tachycardia. This condition requires careful management of oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Tachycardia: The patient has sinus tachycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions (PACs). The etiology is unclear, but it may be related to mild volume overload or mild infection. It needs to be monitored and managed with appropriate medications.
3. S/p Femoral Line Site Bleed: The patient experienced a severe bleed after removal of a venous line with normal INR and platelets. This could be an isolated event, but further evaluation is needed to prevent future bleeding episodes.
4. Delirium: The patient was delirious with an unclear etiology. Differential diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension and end stage
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures now
   transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Primarily caused by
   acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s,
   he has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30%
   FiO2 with shovel mask.  His sats vary widely depending on if he is
   clearing his secretions, but typically improve with suctioning.  Has
   been on levofloxacin, which may be worsening his mental status.  We
   will switch to azithro/ceftriaxone instead, with a plan of 7 days.
   Sputum cultures showed just commensal flora.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 1 of 7.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, f/u I/O
s and PM lytes to reassess need for
   second dose.
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and restart captopril 6.25mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive
   component
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - goal I/Os today even, so we will hold lasix for now.
   #) Hypernatremia: Likely due to diuresis and slight hypovolemia.  We
   will stop diuresing for now, give 1L of free water, and then monitor.
   - f/u PM lytes.
   #) Delerium: Has been persistently delirious with an unclear etiology.
   Differential diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic
   abnormalities etc.  Has had a possible pneumonia, urine negative, blood
   cx pending.  This has improved, and he seems to do best with his family
   at the bedside.
   - Tylenol first, then low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   - repeat UA/culture and blood cultures.
   - PRN zydis for agitation
 has not been required to date.
   - Encourage OOB.
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs. Given concern for congestive heart
   failure will resume patient's home beta blocker and diurese.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar.  Ask ortho how much longer that will be necessary.
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   slightly worse at 1.8.
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - goal today for I/Os is even to avoid further insult.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.
   No signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past
   48 hours.  Appears on labs to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - stop captopril
   - metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal - 1 liter today
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Gout:
   - continue home prednisone
   - holding allopurinol
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy:
   - holding agents while has foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, place NG tube for tube feeds
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin and pneumo boots.
   Access: multiple PIVs, arterial line

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found unconscious in his living apartment and was transferred to the ICU due to hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. 

The patient's current medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is primarily caused by acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, worsened by hypertension and tachycardia. He requires supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation levels above 90%. 

2. Hypernatremia: The patient has high sodium levels, likely due to diuresis and slight hypovolemia. This can be managed by stopping diuretics, providing free water, and monitoring electrolyte levels.

3. Delirium: The patient has been persistently delirious with an unclear etiology. Differential diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities, etc. The delirium may improve with family presence at the bedside and the use of Tylenol or low-dose fentanyl for pain management.

4. Tachycardia: The patient has an unclear etiology of tachycardia. EKGs show sinus tachycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions. Given concern for congestive heart failure, the patient's home beta-blocker will be resumed,

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and was transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient is currently stable but has persistently altered mental status and difficulty clearing secretions. He requires frequent suctioning and is on 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's primary problem is his difficulty clearing secretions, which can lead to recurrent respiratory failure if not managed appropriately.
2. Delirium: The patient has been persistently delirious with an unclear etiology. Differential diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities, etc.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient has improved slightly with 1L of D5W. Further management and free water administration will be needed to correct the electrolyte imbalance.
4. Tachycardia: The patient has an unclear etiology for tachycardia. Metoprolol is being used to control the heart rate.
5. Right Wrist Fracture: The patient has a reduced and casted right wrist fracture, which will require orthopedic follow-up.
6. Dens Fracture: The patient has a type II dens fracture, which is being managed non

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and brought to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. He has been diagnosed with multiple medical complications including electrolyte disorder, altered mental status, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, impaired transfers, gait, aerobic capacity/endurance, balance, and knowledge.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's primary problem is difficulty clearing secretions, which has led to periodic drops in oxygen saturation levels. He is currently on 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, and fluid management needs to be carefully monitored.
3. Delirium: The patient has persistently delirious behavior with an unclear etiology. Differential diagnosis includes medications, infection, and metabolic abnormalities.
4. Tachycardia: The patient has an unclear etiology for his tachycardia. EKGs show sinus tachycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions.
5. Right Wrist Fracture: The patient has a reduced and casted right wrist fracture with no plans for operative intervention.
6. Dens Fracture: The patient has a type II dens fracture and is currently wearing a collar

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,

   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here is stable with persistently altered mental
   status and difficulty clearing secretions.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Initially caused by
   acute on chronic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia, though now his primary problem is his difficulty clearing
   secretions.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s, he
   has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30% FiO2
   with shovel mask.  He is still requiring Q3hr or more frequent
   suctioning.  Switched from levofloxacin to azithro/ceftriaxone out of
   fear of worsening mental status, now day 2 of 7 days.  No organisms on
   sputum.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 2 of 7.
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Given that he is already almost 1L
   positive, will give 40mg lasix x1.
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and restart captopril 6.25mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved yesterday with 1L of D5W.  Today we will
   follow and give added free water if needed.
   - f/u PM lytes.
   #) Delerium: He continues to wax and wane quite a bit.  Yesterday
   afternoon, his sons thought he was improved, this morning on rounds he
   will not even open his eyes and mostly just withdraws from noxious
   stimuli and mumbles in Cantonese.  We have not found a clear infectious
   source, though ICU admission alone in a man with baseline dementia
   could explain his severe delirium.  We worry that we missed something
   that may have caused his initial fall.  We will consult neurology for
   their input in case we are missing some cause of his persistent altered
   mental status.
   - Neurology consult

   stroke at some point.
   - Tylenol first, then low dose fentanyl as needed for pain

   tachycardia with frequent PACs and PVCs. We are trying to control with
   metoprolol QID.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient. 

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure due to acute on chronic heart failure, worsened by hypertension and tachycardia. He is experiencing difficulty clearing secretions and requires frequent suctioning. There is a concern for worsening respiratory status, and the patient is being kept on 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask.

2. Hypernatremia: The patient has an elevated sodium level of 142 mEq/L. The goal is to correct this electrolyte imbalance by providing free water.

3. Delirium: The patient continues to exhibit fluctuating levels of consciousness, ranging from improved to severe delirium. An infectious source has not been found, and there is concern for an underlying cause. A neurology consult has been requested to assess for any missed causes of persistent altered mental status.

4. Tachycardia: The patient has an unclear etiology of tachycardia, with frequent premature atrial contractions (PACs) and premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) seen on EKG. Metoprolol is being used to control the heart rate.

5. Right Wrist Fracture: The patient has a right wrist fracture that has been reduced and casted. No operative intervention is planned.

6. Dens Fracture: The patient also has a dens fracture

Based on the provided information, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient has been experiencing altered mental status, not delirium.
- They have atrial fibrillation (AFIB) and respiratory failure, acute but not ARDS.
- The patient also has impaired transfers, gait, aerobic capacity/endurance, balance, and knowledge.
- The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation and an upper extremity fracture.
- Encephalopathy is present, and the patient is less interactive.
- The patient's right hand is swollen, and they withdraw with movement of fingers but not thumb or wrist.
- Neurological examination is consistent with encephalopathy, and an MRI instead of CT scan is recommended.
- If the patient spikes a new fever despite antibiotics, a lumbar puncture (LP) may be considered.
- The patient is persistently tachycardic and has received an extra dose of metoprolol.
- The patient has been given extra doses of medications such as heparin sodium, furosemide (Lasix), and famotidine (Pepcid).
- The patient has undergone various tests including an ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and chest X-ray.
- The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder, as well as other medical conditions, need to be addressed.
- The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and their disposition is unknown.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided include:

1. Infection: The patient has been experiencing fever and has pending cultures for bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), urine culture, and blood culture. There is also a concern for meningitis if the patient spikes a new fever despite antibiotics.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, and their oxygenation status needs to be closely monitored. The chest X-ray shows increasing left pleural effusion and retrocardiac opacity, indicating possible worsening of respiratory function.

3. Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status and decreased interaction suggest encephalopathy. Further investigation and management are required, including the recommended MRI scan.

4. Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient has atrial fibrillation (AFIB), which may contribute to the persistent tachycardia. Close monitoring of heart rate and rhythm is necessary.

5. Fluid and electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an electrolyte and fluid disorder, as indicated by the abnormal laboratory values. Ongoing monitoring and correction of imbalances are essential.

6. Wound infection or complications: The patient's upper extremity fracture increases the risk of wound infection or other complications. Regular assessment of the wound and surrounding tissues is necessary.

7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Although the right upper extremity ultrasound did not show any DVT, it is still important to monitor the patient for

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is stable from respiratory standpoint but
   active issues are now persistently altered mental status, difficulty
   clearing secretions, R hand swelling.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Initially caused by
   acute on chronic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia, though now his primary problem is his difficulty clearing
   secretions.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s, he
   has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30% FiO2
   with shovel mask.  He is still requiring Q3hr or more frequent
   suctioning.  Switched from levofloxacin to azithro/ceftriaxone out of
   fear of worsening mental status, now day 3 of 7 days.  No organisms on
   sputum.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 3 of 7.
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Will give 40mg IV Lasix this am.
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and continue captopril 12.5mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - continue frequent suctioning to clear secretions
   #) Delerium: He continues to wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to
   communicate with his sons and they think he has improved, when we speak
   to him he doesn
t open his eyes and withdraws from noxious stimuli. We
   have not found a clear infectious source, though ICU admission alone in
   a man with baseline dementia could explain his severe delirium.
   Appreciate Neurology input who think he is encephalopathic and
   recommended MRI yesterday which is preliminarily negative.
   - F/u neuro recs
   - Tylenol first, then low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   - Neuro recs if spikes new fever would need LP. Also watch for
   metabolic abnormalities, none apparent so far
   #) RUE swelling: ultrasound negative yesterday. Does have recent
   history of gout. Appear slightly improved.
   - Continue Prednisone 2.5mg PO qday
   - Consider pulling arterial line
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs and PVCs. We are trying to control with
   metoprolol QID.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   - increase as necessary
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar.  Ask ortho how much longer that will be necessary.
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   improved to 1.1
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - goal today for I/Os is even to avoid further insult.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.5.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - captopril 12.5mg TID and metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal
 even today
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.  We are giving albuterol and
   ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Gout:  continue home prednisone
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: holding agents while he has foley in
   place
   FEN: NG tube w/ tube feeds, replete electrolytes PRN
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin and pneumo boots, Pepcid
   Access: PICC line and A-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with son)
   Communication: Patient,  son [**Name (NI) 3080**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10783**]
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, likely to floor tomorrow.

   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and continue captopril 12.5mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - continue frequent suctioning to clear secretions
 will need to touch
   base with family re: putting a trach in
   #) Delerium: He continues to wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to
   communicate with his sons and they think he has improved, when we speak
   to him he doesn
t open his eyes and withdraws from noxious stimuli. We
   have not found a clear infectious source, though ICU admission alone in
   a man with baseline dementia could explain his severe delirium.
   Appreciate Neurology input who think he is encephalopathic and
   recommended MRI yesterday which is preliminarily negative.
   - Start standing Tylenol instead of prn to control his pain
   - F/u neuro recs

   metabolic abnormalities, none apparent so far.
   #) RUE swelling: ultrasound negative yesterday. Does have recent
   history of gout. Appear slightly improved.
   - Continue Prednisone 2.5mg PO qday
   - Pulling arterial line today
   - Plain film of R hand
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs and PVCs. We are trying to control with
   metoprolol QID.
   - Will increase Metoprolol 25 mg PO QID  to 37.5 QID
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for

   - orthopedics followup

   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and was transferred from the TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. Currently, the patient is stable from a respiratory standpoint but has active issues including persistent altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient initially had acute on chronic heart failure worsened by hypertension and tachycardia. Although he is now stable, he still requires frequent suctioning to clear secretions and is being kept on 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask. 
2) Delirium: The patient continues to wax and wane quite a bit, with severe delirium. Neurology input is recommended, and an MRI was performed yesterday, which is preliminary negative.
3) Right Upper Extremity Swelling: The patient has swelling in the right upper extremity, which was negative on ultrasound yesterday. It could be related to gout or deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
4) Tachycardia: The patient has persistent tachycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions (PACs) and premature ventricular contractions (PVCs). Metoprolol is being

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly male who presented with respiratory failure following a fall and subsequent delirium. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with an acute exacerbation, as well as a fracture in the C2 vertebrae and a wrist fracture. 

The patient's current medical complications include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient continues to have secretions with difficulty clearing. He is currently on antibiotics (azithromycin and ceftriaxone) for respiratory infection.

2. C2 fracture: The patient has a fracture in the C2 vertebrae, and a cervical collar has been applied to stabilize the neck.

3. Right hand swelling: The patient has swelling in the right hand, which is negative on ultrasound. Plain film of the hand/wrist should be checked as well, and the radial arterial line should be pulled.

4. Delirium: The patient is experiencing delirium, and an MRI without acute changes was performed.

Other issues mentioned in the note include impaired transfers, impaired gait, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired balance, and impaired knowledge. These impairments are likely related to the patient's overall critical condition and age.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory failure, fractures, delirium, and other medical complications.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and is currently in the ICU with multiple medical issues. The patient has hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling. He also has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, left wrist fracture, dens fracture, chronic kidney disease, anemia, congestive heart failure exacerbation, COPD, gout, and benign prostatic hypertrophy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern due to his history of COPD and acute exacerbation. He requires frequent suctioning and has periodic drops in oxygen saturation levels, indicating ongoing respiratory compromise.

2. Delirium: The patient continues to exhibit delirium, characterized by waxing and waning mental status. This could be due to hospital/ICU delirium, infection, or other underlying causes. Neurology input is recommended, and an MRI was done, which was negative for any acute process.

3. Fever: The patient has had fevers despite being afebrile for a while. The source of the fever is unknown, and recent cultures have been negative. Imaging shows atelectasis and bilateral opacities on the chest, raising concerns for pneumonia

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and was transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient has been stable from a respiratory standpoint but has active issues including persistent altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient's fluid balance has been positive, and there have been concerns about his electrolyte levels. IV Lasix will be given today to address this issue.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient has been experiencing frequent delirium, with waxing and waning consciousness. Neurology input has been requested, and an MRI was performed, which showed no acute process. The patient is currently febrile, and further cultures are pending.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient initially presented with hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, which is now being managed with oxygen supplementation and frequent suctioning. A tracheostomy may be considered due to the continued respiratory needs.
4. Right Upper Extremity Swelling: The patient has swelling in his right hand, which was initially suspected to be due to deep vein thrombosis (DVT). However, an ultrasound ruled out DVT, and the swelling is currently being

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is more stable from respiratory
   standpoint but active issues are now persistently altered mental
   status, difficulty clearing secretions, R hand swelling.
   #) Hypotension: patient dropped pressures yesterday after receiving
   lasix and captopril and took most of the day to recover, eventually
   receiving 1800ccs in boluses and running 4 liters positive for the
   day.  Today his pressures have improved, but we will stay away from
   captopril for awhile now, and run him even for several days before
   being more aggressive in our diuresis.  Given his tachycardia, we will
   continue metoprolol.
   - metoprolol 37.5mg TID.  No captopril
   - goal I/O
s even.
   #) AFib with RVR: currently still in AFib but without RVR.  Alternates
   between A fib and sinus rhythm w/ frequent PACs and PVCs.  Given the
   hypotension above, we will try to control his rate with digoxin in the
   hope of controlling tachycardia without dropping his pressures.
   - PO digoxin load.  1 gram in first 24 hours, then 0.125mg daily.
   - Metoprolol as above
   - Restarted anticoagulation yesterday with Coumadin.  Plan is to
   anticoagulate while he is hospitalized, but likely send him home
   without coumadin given his fall risk.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: His secretions have
   been improving.  Switched from levofloxacin to azithro/ceftriaxone out
   of fear of worsening mental status, now day 4 of 7 days, and Vanc was
   added [**2109-11-7**] when pt was febrile and had AF with RVR.  No recent
   organisms.
    - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 4 of 7.
   - Vanc added [**11-7**] pm = day 1 --> will need ABx approval
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Was 2L positive through yesterday,
   will give 40mg IV Lasix today
   - Increased Metoprolol yesterday to 37.5 qid and kept Captopril 12.5
   TID --> will need to watch HR and BP today with new onset AF with RVR
   and increase as tolerated if necessary
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - From a respiratory status, he appears pretty good today, satting well
   on humidified facemask and occasional shovel mask
   - Continue as is, try to wean O2 as tolerated
   #)  Fevers: Unsure of the source. Pt was afebrile for quite a while
   then spiked yesterday to 102.
   - F/u Cx's from when he spiked last night
   - Would re-Cx if spikes
   - Recent imaging includes CXR's with L retrocardiac opacity, called as
   atelectasis previously. Last CT chest with B opacities concern for PNA
   vs atelectasis. MRI head negative. Could consider CT torso to look for
   infection, but likely low yield
   - R PICC was just placed so not likely source.
   - On Azithro/Ceftriaxone and now added Vanc
   #) Delerium: He continues to wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to
   communicate with his sons and they think he has improved, when we speak
   to him he doesn
t open his eyes and withdraws from noxious stimuli. We
   have not found a clear infectious source, may have hospital/ICU
   delirium.
   - F/u neuro recs.  No plan for LP for now.
   - PT consult to evaulate deconditioning
   - Yesterday started standing Tylenol to try and control pain
   #) RUE swelling: ultrasound negative for DVT. Does have recent history
   of gout. Appear slightly improved.
   - Continue Prednisone 2.5mg PO qday, hesitant to increase in already
   delirious pt
   - Pulled art line from R hand yesterday
   - Plain films of R hand without prelim reads --> follow up today
   - will consult hand surgery to evaluate for any fluid
   collection/abscess
   #) Left wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for operative
   intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - Touched base with orthopedics who said needs to keep on 6-8wks from
   injury and then f/u with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 10823**]

   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - goal today for I/Os is even to avoid further insult, but yesterday 2L
   positive, will give Lasix today
    #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.5.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen, currently outdates [**11-10**]
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
    #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once today, then follow-up
   - captopril 12.5mg TID and metoprolol 37.5 mg QID
   - I/O goal
 even today, with Lasix as above

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. 

The patient has multiple medical complications, including electrolyte and fluid disorder, altered mental status, atrial fibrillation (AFib), respiratory failure, upper extremity fracture, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. 

The patient's current medications include ceftriaxone, azithromycin, vancomycin, lasix, captopril, metoprolol, digoxin, prednisone, and albuterol/ipratropium nebulizers. 

The patient's recent laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and slightly elevated creatinine level. 

Imaging studies reveal findings consistent with gout in the carpus, distal radius, and ulna, as well as a suspected nondisplaced fracture at the lunate and distal radius. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure ranging from 100/24 to 124/34 mmHg, heart rate between 103 and 117 bpm, respiratory rate around 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 95%. 

The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and further diagnostic tests and

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. 

The patient's current issues include altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling. The altered mental status is characterized by intermittent periods of confusion and disorientation, with fluctuating levels of consciousness. The patient's sons believe that he appears better at times but may be noncompliant with commands. 

The respiratory failure initially caused by acute on chronic heart failure, worsened by hypertension and tachycardia, is now primarily due to difficulty clearing secretions. The patient is still requiring frequent suctioning and is on supplemental oxygen. 

The right upper extremity swelling is believed to be related to gout, as confirmed by imaging, and is currently being managed with prednisone. 

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and is currently being treated with metoprolol and will restart anticoagulation with Coumadin.

Other medical conditions and complications include a dens fracture, left wrist fracture, chronic kidney disease, anemia, congestive heart failure exacerbation, and gout.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and had odontoid and right wrist fractures. He was transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. In the ICU, he is more stable from a respiratory standpoint but has active issues including persistently altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and R hand swelling. The patient's current conditions and medical complications include electrolyte & fluid disorder, altered mental status (not delirium), atrial fibrillation (AFIB), respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS), upper extremity fracture, and impaired gait, balance, knowledge, transfers, and aerobic capacity/endurance. The patient's recent lab results show some abnormalities such as elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, and elevated creatinine levels. Imaging studies reveal findings consistent with gout in the carpus, distal radius, and ulna, and fifth metacarpal head, suspected nondisplaced fracture at the lunate and distal radius, and negative MRI head. The patient has multiple medical problems and is currently being treated with various medications including antibiotics, diuretics, anticoagulants, and medications for COPD and heart failure. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory status, delirium

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and was transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient is currently more stable from a respiratory standpoint but has active issues including altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling.

Medical Complications:
1. Electrolyte & Fluid Disorder: The patient has had ongoing fluid balance issues, with positive fluid balance yesterday and plans to give Lasix today.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient continues to wax and wane quite a bit, with intermittent improvement. He is able to communicate with his sons but does not open his eyes and withdraws from noxious stimuli. No clear infectious source has been found, and he may have hospital/ICU delirium.
3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response: The patient is currently still in atrial fibrillation but without rapid ventricular response. Metoprolol was increased, and Coumadin will be restarted today.
4. Right Upper Extremity Swelling: The patient has swelling in his right upper extremity, which is slightly improved. An ultrasound was negative for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and he has a recent history of gout.
5. Left Wrist Fracture: The patient now has a reduced and casted left wrist fracture, with no plans for operative intervention.
6. Dens Fracture: The patient has a type II dens fracture, which is being managed non-operatively with a hard collar.
7. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's baseline creatinine is improved from 1.4-1.6 to 1.1.
8. Anemia: The patient has a baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, currently at 23.5, possibly due to anemia of chronic disease.
9. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient may have had an exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe aortic regurgitation and moderate mitral regurgitation.
10. COPD: The patient's COPD history is unclear, with CO2 retention at baseline and home oxygen use. Inhalers have been prescribed but not used at home.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Gout: The patient may have gout contributing to his right hand swelling.
2. Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: The patient has a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy, currently on hold due to the presence of a foley catheter.
3. Pneumonia vs Atelectasis: There is concern for pneumonia versus atelectasis in the patient's chest imaging.
4. Deep Vein Thrombosis: Although the ultrasound was negative, there is still a possibility of deep vein thrombosis in the patient's right upper extremity.
5. Delirium: The patient may have hospital/ICU delirium or encephalopathy.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient may have acute respiratory failure, not ARDS.
7. Impaired Transfer: The patient may have impaired transfers and mobility.
8. Impaired Balance: The patient may have impaired balance.
9. Impaired Gait: The patient may have impaired gait.
10. Impaired Knowledge: The patient may have impaired knowledge.

Please note that this is a summary of the progress note, and it is important to review the entire document for

   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is more stable from respiratory
   standpoint but active issues are now persistently altered mental
   status, difficulty clearing secretions, R hand swelling.
   #) Hypotension: patient dropped pressures yesterday after receiving
   lasix and captopril and took most of the day to recover, eventually
   receiving 1800ccs in boluses and running 4 liters positive for the
   day.  Today his pressures have improved, but we will stay away from
   captopril for awhile now, and run him even for several days before
   being more aggressive in our diuresis.  Given his tachycardia, we will
   continue metoprolol.

   - goal I/O
s even.

   between A fib and sinus rhythm w/ frequent PACs and PVCs.  Given the
   hypotension above, we will try to control his rate with digoxin in the
   hope of controlling tachycardia without dropping his pressures.
   - PO digoxin load.  1 gram in first 24 hours, then 0.125mg daily.
   - Metoprolol as above
   - Restarted anticoagulation yesterday with Coumadin.  Plan is to
   anticoagulate while he is hospitalized, but likely send him home
   without coumadin given his fall risk.
   #) RUE swelling: Plain-films showed a small fracture of his wrist which
   is the likely source of his swelling.  There were also signs of gout on
   the plain film, which could explain his leukocytosis and fever.  He was
   seen by plastics who splinted his hand.
   - f/u plastics recs.  Can also ask them whether they would be willing

   consult.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment prior to admission and had odontoid and right wrist fractures. He was transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. Currently, he is more stable but has active issues including altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling.

Medical Complications:

1. Electrolyte & Fluid Disorder: The patient has shown hypotension, which improved after receiving Lasix and captopril. However, he took most of the day to recover and eventually received 1800ccs in boluses and ran 4 liters positive for the day. His pressures have improved, but caution is advised with diuresis due to his tachycardia. He will continue metoprolol and digoxin to control his rate.

2. Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): The patient is currently still in AFib but without RVR. He alternates between AFib and sinus rhythm with frequent PACs and PVCs. Digoxin is being started to control his rate, and metoprolol will continue to be used.

3. Right Upper Extremity Swelling: Plain-films showed a small fracture of the wrist, which is the likely source of swelling. There were also signs

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. His current active issues include altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of COPD and is currently on mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of further respiratory failure due to underlying lung disease and complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia.
2. Delirium: The patient is experiencing altered mental status, which can be attributed to various causes such as medication side effects, infection, or ICU delirium. This condition needs to be closely monitored and managed.

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is more stable from respiratory
   standpoint but active issues are now low grade fevers and leukocytosis
   of unclear origin.
   #)  Fevers/leukocytosis: Patient is intermittently febrile and now has
   a rising leukocytosis.  Cultures have not grown anything to date, but
   he has persistently been on antibiotics.  This could be from gout.  C
   diff negative yesterday.  CXR appears unchanged.  LFTs normal.
   Pathogens that we are not covering include pseudomonas, VRE and ESBL
   klebsiella.  For now we will stop azithro (completed course) and change
   ceftriaxone for zosyn for empiric coverage of pseudomonas and continue
   vancomycin for potential MRSA
   - rheum consult
   - F/u cultures, continue to re-culture if spikes.
   - he has had a left-sided pleural effusion for several days.  Consider
   tapping if persistently febrile.
   - recheck C.diff as he has had a long abx course.
   - R PICC was just placed so not likely source.  Will consider pulling
   if we can obtain other access.
   - Change to Vanc/Zosyn as above.
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.  Has
   been fluid positive for multiple days now and appears to have
   increasing effusion on CXR.  We will shoot for I/O even for now, and if
   he tolerates that well, can diurese further.
   - Already got Lasix 60mg IV this morning.  Can give 80mg today in the
   afternoon if pressures hold.
   - metoprolol 37.5 mg QID
   - I/O goal
 even today, with Lasix as above
   #) AFib with RVR: dig loaded.  Will check a PM level and then decide on
   a daily dose.
   - Metoprolol as above
   - Restarted anticoagulation yesterday with Coumadin.  Plan is to
   anticoagulate while he is hospitalized, but likely send him home
   without coumadin given his fall risk.  Follow INR and titrate coumadin.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Has not had episodes of
   desaturation for several days but continues to require frequent
   suctioning.
    - Vanc/Zosyn as above.
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Will give lasix cautiously after
   hypotension above.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - Continue as is, try to wean O2 as tolerated
   #) Delerium: more interactive the last couple of days but continues to
   wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to communicate with his sons and
   they think he has improved.  Almost definitely has hospital/ICU
   delirium.
   - Should continue working with PT.
   - Standing Tylenol for pain control.
   #) Hypotension: resolved.  Will need close monitoring while being
   diuresed.
   #) Left and right wrist fractures: Left side reduced and casted.  Right
   side splinted.  No plans for operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - Touched base with orthopedics who said needs to keep on 6-8wks from
   injury and then f/u with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 10823**]
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   improved to 1.0
   - trend creatinine
    #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.5.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.  We are giving albuterol and
   ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: holding agents while he has foley in
   place

   are very involved.  We may have to discuss PEG tube placement with them
   relatively soon.

   going to acute rehab than to the floor.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and transferred from the TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. 

The patient's current issues include fevers/leukocytosis of unclear origin, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, delirium, hypotension, left and right wrist fractures, dens fracture, chronic kidney disease, anemia, COPD, and benign prostatic hypertrophy.

The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, exacerbation of congestive heart failure, infection due to persistent leukocytosis and fever, further deterioration in mental status, development of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to immobilization, and worsening renal function.

It is important to monitor the patient closely for any signs of deterioration and adjust the treatment plan accordingly. This may involve optimizing respiratory support, managing fluid balance, administering appropriate antibiotics, and addressing any other acute issues that may arise. Additionally, long-term care considerations such as rehabilitation and nutritional support should also be taken into account.

The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living area and transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient has been more stable from a respiratory standpoint but now presents with low-grade fevers and leukocytosis of unclear origin. He has a history of gout, which could be a potential cause of the symptoms.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient's intermittent fevers and rising leukocyte count may indicate an infection. Since cultures have not grown anything to date, broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started empirically. The patient's rheumatology consult is pending to rule out gout as the cause of the fever and leukocytosis.

2. Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): The patient's history of CHF complicated by severe AR (aortic regurgitation) and moderate MR (mitral regurgitation) is concerning. Fluid resuscitation and holding home medications have exacerbated his condition, leading to an increasing effusion on the chest X-ray. The plan is to aim for an even fluid balance and diurese further if tolerated.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment and was transferred from the TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient's active issues now include low-grade fevers and leukocytosis of unclear origin. 

Assessment and Plan:
1. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient is intermittently febrile and has a rising leukocytosis. Cultures have not grown anything to date, but he has persistently been on antibiotics. This could be due to gout. C diff negative yesterday. CXR appears unchanged. LFTs normal. He has completed a course of Azithro, and the Ceftriaxone has been changed to Zosyn (empiric coverage of Pseudomonas), and continuing Vanco (for MRSA coverage).

2. Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications. We will aim for I/O even today, with Lasix as above.

3. AFib with RVR: Dig loaded, level was 1.8 yesterday pm, only getting dosed every day. Will discuss on rounds starting on qday dosing.

4. Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Has not had episodes of desaturation for several days but continues to require frequent suctioning.

5. Delirium: More interactive the last couple of days but continues to wax and wane quite a bit. He is able to communicate with his sons and they think he has improved. Almost definitely has hospital/ICU delirium.

6. Hypotension: Resolved. Will need close monitoring while being diuresed.

7. Left and right wrist fractures: Left side reduced and casted. Right side splinted. No plans for operative intervention.

8. Dens Fracture: Type II dens fracture. Non-operative. Currently in [Location] J Collar.

9. Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6. Currently improved to 1.0

10. Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.5. Had large bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since. Appears on labs to be anemia of chronic disease.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Gout flare: The patient's low-grade fevers and leukocytosis could be due to a gout flare. It is important to continue monitoring his symptoms and lab results.

2. Congestive Heart Failure exacerbation: The patient's history of congestive heart failure and the presence of severe AR and moderate MR increase the risk of exacerbation. Close monitoring of his fluid balance and use of diuretics are necessary.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of COPD and acute respiratory failure indicate a high risk for further respiratory complications. Frequent suctioning and close monitoring of oxygenation are important.

4. Delirium: The patient's fluctuating mental status suggests ongoing delirium. Close monitoring and involvement of the physical therapy department are crucial for his care.

5. Fractures: The patient has left and right wrist fractures, which require appropriate management, including splinting and potential casting.

6. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease needs ongoing monitoring, especially considering his recent improvement in creatinine levels.

7. Anemia: The patient's anemia of chronic disease should be monitored, and appropriate interventions may be necessary.

Potential Medical Complications in ICU:
1. Fluid overload: The patient's history of congestive heart failure and recent fluid resuscitation increase the risk of fluid overload. Close monitoring of fluid balance and diuretic therapy are important.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of COPD and acute respiratory failure indicate a high risk for further respiratory complications in the ICU.

3. Delirium: The patient's fluctuating mental status suggests ongoing delirium in the ICU. Close monitoring and involvement of the physical therapy department are crucial for his care.

4. Infection: The patient's persistent fevers and leukocytosis indicate a possible ongoing infection. Close monitoring of lab results and appropriate antibiotic therapy are necessary.

5. Bleeding: The patient's history of a large bleed from the fem line site raises concern for bleeding complications in the ICU.

6. Hypotension: The patient's recent resolution of hypotension should be closely monitored, especially during diuresis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure.
- He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and had odontoid and right wrist fractures.
- The patient was transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently more stable.
- Active issues include low-grade fevers, leukocytosis of unclear origin, and delirium.
- The patient has been intermittently febrile and now has a rising leukocytosis. Cultures have not grown anything to date, but he has persistently been on antibiotics.
- He completed a course of Azithro and changed to Zosyn (empiric coverage of Pseudomonas) and continues on Vanco (for MRSA coverage).
- Rheum recommends Colchicine for gout treatment; no steroids at this time.
- The patient has severe AR and moderate MR in the setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
- He started Lasix 40 IV bid, metoprolol 37.5 mg QID, and his I/O goal is euvolemia to negative.
- The patient was in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response but is now in sinus rhythm.
- His INR was very high yesterday, so he will convert and stop Coumadin.
- He continues to require frequent suctioning and uses albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers.
- The patient has hospital/ICU delirium.
- His gout is being treated with Prednisone and Colchicine.
- The patient's hypotension has resolved, and he will need close monitoring while being diuresed.
- His left wrist fracture was reduced and casted, while his right wrist fracture is splinted.
- The patient has a Type II dens fracture, which is non-operative.
- His chronic kidney disease is improving, and his baseline creatinine is in the range of 1.4-1.6.
- He has anemia of chronic disease with a hematocrit of 23.3.
- The patient's COPD is unclear, and he has a history of CO2 retention at baseline.
- He has benign prostatic hypertrophy and is holding agents while he has a foley in place.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient's intermittent fevers and rising leukocytosis may indicate an ongoing infection. Continued monitoring and re-culture are necessary to identify the source of infection.
2. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient's history of congestive heart failure (CHF) and exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure pose a risk for fluid overload and worsening cardiac function. Close monitoring of fluid balance and diuresis is essential.
3. Gout: The patient's gout can lead to acute flares and potential complications such as kidney stones or renal dysfunction. Monitoring his uric acid levels and adjusting treatment accordingly is important.
4. Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's history of CO2 retention and dependence on supplemental oxygen puts him at risk for respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation parameters is crucial.
5. Delirium: The patient's delirium increases the risk of falls, complications, and prolonged hospitalization. Frequent reorientation, appropriate pain management, and minimizing unnecessary medications are essential.
6. Fractures: The patient's multiple fractures, including the odontoid and wrist fractures, may lead to complications such as nonunion, malunion, or pressure ulcers. Regular orthopedic follow-up and proper immobilization are necessary.
